header: Perl turned 24 this week. Happy birthday!
Last week 175 people clicked on the job post at Best Practical. Very impressive :)
The Perl Maven courses I started month ago got quite good reaction and I am now tense as I have not finished recording all the material yet.
This weeks issue seemed a bit slim. I think most of the action is in the Advant calendars so I'll link to some entries there too:

entries.title: CPAN - As Seen From Space!
entries.text: This was announced in many channels but here you can also see some funny comments such as 'Thanks for spending your time developing a way for me to waste mine :)'. Grant McLean created a map of all CPAN. You can slice it and dice it. See the authors, the dependencies or the users of a module.

entries.title: Booking.com Donate Another €100,000
entries.text: This donation is towards the development of perl 5. I wish other companies would now approach The Perl Foundation and offer further donations to enable larger grants for CPAN module development and for Perl 6 development.

entries.title: Alternative Dancer Templating Engines
entries.text: Michał Wojciechowski reviews 3 templating systems that work with Dancer: Tiny (based on Template::Tiny), Tenjin and Haml which coming from the Ruby on Rails folks.

entries.title: When slower is better: Secure your passwords
entries.text: Sebastian Willing explains how to store passwords in a very secure way and how to maintain or even increase the security level while cracking passwords is getting faster and faster.

entries.title: Writing API clients in Perl and Python
entries.text: Mark Allen has implemented the API of the Ge.tt file sharing service in both languages and praises CPAN and its toolchain for making his life easier.

entries.title: Stick it to them...[
entries.text: The Perl Foundation has a new sticker

entries.title: MetaCPAN logo competition announced
entries.text: Want to get $400 and eternal fame? Just design a logo for MetaCPAN!

entries.title: Learning music notes with Perl
entries.text: Viacheslav Tykhanovskyi (vti) bought a MIDI 2 USB interface and had to try it with Perl. You will see how he used MIDI::ALSA from CPAN to make it work.

entries.title: Bailador — A small Dancer clone
entries.text: A minimal Dancer clone implemented in Perl 6. Unlike the real Dancer which is very jumpy, this fits more people who like slow dance. I like both.
